cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.p:
The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been dis-
continued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will,
however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if
return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or
abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six
months of arrival.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie
div.p:
Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fornight from Hamburg:
weekly from Antwerp every 4 weeks from Bordeaux direct to Alexandria:
homewards every 2 weeks from Alexandria for Rotterdam and Hamburg.
Goods forwarded at throughrates from all German Railway Stations on direct
Billie of Lading to Alexandria, Cairo, Syria, etc. Spcial facilities for con-
veyance of cotton, etc from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German
manufacturing towns. STEAMERS AT ALEXANDRIA
Expect :Jan. 16 S.S. Tinos from Antwerp bound for Rotterdamn & Hamburg.
Expect :Jan. 20 S.S. Paros from Antwerp--Jan 27th S.S. Enos from Hamburg.
For tarif and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS. Alexandria Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS

Express steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA,
MITYLENE and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-deluxe for
Vienna, Paris, and London

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. and Port said every Sunday at
6 p.m. for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damarous).
TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTIA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and
LIMASSOL (Cyrprus)

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning
from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah
continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden, Intermediate steamers
do not preceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B. - Deck chains provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria,
Cairo. Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.

S.S. Tabor now on the berth, will sail on or about Thursday, 17th January,, to be followed by S.S. Seti.

div.head: CASSA DI SCONTO E DI RISPARMIO.

p.unclear:
The Cassa Di Sconto a Di Risparmio effects all Barnking operations, such as Discount, Payments, Loans on Title, Deeds and
Goods: Letters of Credit issued. Drafts and telegraphic transfers on principal towns of Egypt and aboard. Custody of Titles Deeds,
Purchases and sale of Debetuary or other valuables; Current accounts opened. The "Cassa de Sconte a de Rispariami" recieves
money in deposits at following rates; - 2 o/o for sight, 3 1/2 for 6 months, 4 1/2 o/o for 1 year and over. The Savings Bank
recieves deposits from P.T. 20 up to 20,000 at the rate of 3 1/4 o/o per annum

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation.
div.p:
Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice). Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m.
arrive Brindisi Tuesday at 5 a.m. in time for the Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London,
leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Trieste Wednesdays about 11 a.m. connecting with the Train de
Luxe, Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London Fridays 4.50 p.m.
Steamers leave Alexandria every Thursday 10 a.m.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line. Steamer leaves Alexandria about 7, 15, 21, 29 January, (4 p.m.)

Far East Lines. DEPARTURES FROM PORT SAID: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penan, Singapore,
Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama and Jobe, 3 Feb., 6 March, 3 April, 4 May.
To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 7, 22 Jan., 7, 22 Feb., 7, 23 March.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon & Calcutta about 18 Jan., 18 Feb., 18 March, 18 Apr., 18 May.
For information apply to the Agents: Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez and Khartum.
Special rates for Egyptian officials, members of Army of Occupation and their families. 31-12-90

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. Steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:-

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia,
Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the
Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now
a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other anciest ruins and the Venetian fortification,
the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello" and of Ford's "lover's Melancholy."
The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.

Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the
General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248-31-12-907

div.head: Grand Continental Hotel.
div.p:
Open all the year. Unrivalle position in centre of Cairo, opposite Khedival Opera House and Esbekieh

div.head: SILENCE OF RUSSIA.
div.p:
It is vain to dogmatise on the signs of
revolution. With different nations revolution
will accomplish itself in different ways. In
France is seen a fiery, frantic outburt, pro-
ducing horrors that leave an indelible mark on
the imaginations of men, England changes the
ruling dyansty from Stuart to Hanover with
the calm matter-of-factness which it displays
in the ordinary affairs of life. Neither affords
any criterion from which to judge the prob-
abilities in Russia. Whether or not revvolut-
tion is brewing there, who shall decide. Only
he who possesses infallible knowledge of the
Russian character. And where shall such a
man be found?

Without pretending to find portent in St.
Petersburg, says the "Evening standard and
St. James's Gazette," we would draw attetion
to the strange state of feeling there. Assassina-
tion has followed assassination. The Terrorists
are said to have drawn up a list of prominent
adminstrators whom they have condemned to
death, and on that list are working with
deliberate determination. The first three
names have been crossed out. Theri owners
have fallen to the murderers revolver. The
fourth name is that of Admiral Dubassoff,
whose fate yet hangs in the balance. now, this
list made or may not exit, but there is so firm a
belief in it that the threatened men have come
to regard themselves as actually doomed. The
City Perfect, having received a letter warning
him that he would be killed on such and such
a day, felt that his hour had come, and on the
fatal morning, says the "Telegraph" corres-
pondent with the authority of a member of
the family, when setting out for the inagura-
tion of the new church, he kissed his children with
unwanted tenderness and blessed them with
great fervour. General Pavloff, having reason
to think thathe was on the list, never ventured
out of his house on foot, aking exercise in a
little garden of a few square feet. Admiral
Dubassof declines to take these precautions.
He walks abroad as uaul, faicng danger in the
open -- perhaps in the Oriental faith, strength-
ened by the fate of Pavloff, that if death is to
come it will not be barred by walls and drawn
swords. The other day the report was spread
that he has been assassinated, and was
instantly accepted. Everybody is prepared for
it. Attention seems to have been diverted for the
oment from all others and to have concentraed on the Admiral.

An appaling state of things. This cold-
blooded advertisement of the next vistim, and
the public confidence that the sacrifice will be
made, strikes one as infinitely more horrible
than mob passion venting itself in tumult and
blood. The assassinations cause no surpise.
When they are reported the people accepted them
philopsophically. We fancy we hear them
mururing "kismet" and see them bowing
their heads not before the will of God but
before the will of the Terrorists. The idea
Fate has possesses them and the so called
guardians of order so completely that few
and feeble attempts are put forth to stay
the hand of the avenger. Openly threatned
as the Prefect was, the police took no effec-
tive precautions to defend him. The assasin
of Pavloff gained admittance to the house on
the flimsiest of pretexts to take a hotliday abroad. The
brave ones who remain adopt the attitude of
stories rather than that of strong men strug-
gling against adversity. All that is ventured
is to hand the murdered who has done his work,
and wait for an opportnity of handing the
next.

Ordinary, undistinguished, unthreatened,
people do not talk of the progress of the Terror
as they walk around the streets. It is not safe
to do so. For long it has not been safe to talk
in Russia. Yet we hear of the "notorous
sympathy of the public with the criminals".
We have besides that general statements that
atual words, declared to be characteristic of
the feeling of a great class, of the mother of
Ignsteiff's assassin -- a prosperious, educated
woman. "Don't think, darling," she said to
her son, "that I am going to reproach you.
On the contrary, I have nothing but priase for
your action. You behaved as a true Christian.
You have bibly laid down your life for your
racing through the streets tongues did begin
to wag. What they uttered was not horror of
the murder, but approbation of the murderer.

When things come to this pass in a great
city its superficial calm - that is to say, its
freedom from violent general upheaval such
as is suppored the precursor of revolution - is
no matter for congratulation but cause for
anxiety graver than than created by the
outbreaks of a few peasants ina re mote corner
of the land. It made be said that if St. Peters-
burg is ill disposed the rest of the country
will be hard to rouse. Revolutions, howvwer,
are often manufactured and carried through
in a capital, and the nation follows the capital,
raityfing its decision. Whether revolution
be brooding over St. Petersburg we cannot
satisfy ourselves, nor can anybody satisfy us.
But the silence of Russia - the terrible malig-
nant, mysterious silence - is more ominous
than the uprour of Bloody Sunday.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p:
The yacht Coronet arrived at Alexandria
to day from Port Said.

The Khedive has approved and ratified the
convention signed last year at the conference
held at Rome for the foundation of an Interna-
tional Institute of Agriculture.

The inland and foreign money order services
and the specie packet service have been
extend-
ed to the following post offices: - Nashart
Gharbieh), Sinun (Fayoum). aand Mahamid
(Assouan).

A few days ago, a native of Nahiet Sina-
nieh, Damietta, was attacked by a savage
camel, which seized hi by the teeth and
began to swing him to and gro, lashing him
against the ground until the poor man succumd-
ed to his injuries.

Yesterday afternoon, an Aunstrian landowner
at Kafrel Sighar, near Kafra Zayat, had an
altercation with two feaalbeen, who eventually
attached him. The Austrian took his gun and
wounded one of them. An inquiry has been
opened by the Austrian consular authorities
at ALexandria.

During the last week only three cases of
plague were reported, and no further case of
outbreak of the disease has been notified for
the last 48 hours. We wonder - should plague
have happily died out by the summer - what
pretext will be found byt he Ottoman author-
ities for the imposition of quarantine on
arrivals from Egypt, and notably at the Syrian,
ports.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions supressed by our correspondents, but we wish in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits-few discussion.

div.head: THE LEBANON.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

p.hi: Sir,-- Io "L'Orient" of the 6th inst. the public bas been made to under tand the true state of affairs in Mt. Lebanon, which has been misrepresented as being in perfect anáreby and tarmoil by some newspaper which has repted its columns to the enemies of H.E. Muzaffer Pasha for a period which expires when the Governor General of Lebanon is appointed for the next five years,

div.p: But in "L'Orient" of the 8th inst. a correspondent has ate opted to confirm the false piotare referred to by giving fresh addition to the false recital of everts narrated by the paper.
Thinking it useless to prove the falsehood of every story narrated by the discouter ted, I have taken at different intervale, some parts of...

div.head: ROYALTY AT PORT SAID.
div.p: ARRIVAL OF DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
(FROM OUR OWN CORESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Wednesday.
The Duke and Dacbess of Connaught arrived bere ýesterilay on the P. and 0. steamer Marmora. The Doke is bound for Ceylon and Hong Kong, and will spend a few days in Egypt on his retarn.

Their Royal Highneses were welcomed by Mr. D. A. Cameron, HB.M.'s. Consol General, Mohamed Moubeb Pasho, Governor of the Canal, accompanied by Miralai Thomas Shalek Bey, Commandant of Police, and M. Dumont, on behalf of the Spez Canal Company. The Royal party landed on the company's wharf, and proceeded to the residence of the company, where they spent the night.
A picket of police under the orders of Saghcolaghaesi Moore, rendered military honours.

The Italian cruiser Calabria also arrived here yesterday with HR. H. the Duke of Udina on board. The two Dukes exchanged visits this morning. The Marmora fl-w the Royal Standard. The Duke ot. Connaught received several officials on his arrival.
The Italian Cruiser Calabria coaled this morning.. The Duke of Udina bad lanch at the Eastern Exchange.
Rain has fallen since early yesterday morning and shows no signs of abating.

div.head: QUARANTINE.
div.p:
A telegram from Constantinple states that
arrivals in Turkish ports from the litteral ex-
tending from Lith to Et Wedl are subjected
to five days quarantine, disinfection, and de-
ratisation. The measures applied to arrivals
from Suez, Koussier, and Suakin have been
removed.

Arrivals from the litteral between Lith and
El Wedj are also subjected to the usual
quarantine restrictions in Egyptian ports.

div.head: DIVORCE OF A PRINCESS.
div.p: Princess Kamel Pasha Padel, says "Al Mosyad,” has divorced his wife, Princess Fatimeb Hanem Efendi, whom he married last year. The lady is the widow of the late Mopshawi Pasha, and has now lost her title of Princess. "The divorce," adds our contemporary, "is stated to have been due to some persona! difference between the Prince and his wife, and not to fioancial reasons. We understand, bowever, that the latter was the real motive of the divorce."

div.head: THE OASES SURVEY.
div.p: The announcement that appeared in our columns yesterday, to the effect that the Egyptian Government bas decided to make a Satvey of the four Oases in the Libyan desert...

div.head: EGYPTS GOLD IMPORTS.
div.p: THE TOTALS FOR 1906

The total amount of specie imported into Egypt during the past year amounted to LB 9,077,402, as against L.B. 4,782,215 in 1905. These figures show that specie arrived here last year to the value of LE 4,295,187 more than in 1905, an increase of over four and a quarter millions in twelve months. These figures are more significant when it is considered that the total exports of specie from Egypt last year only amounted to LE 2,067,706, as against LE. 3,869,939 in 1906, & decrease in the amount of gold exported of LE. 1,802,233. In other words, Egypt received over four and a qqarter millions more gold last year than in the year before and exported nearly two millions less.

The total specie received from England in 1906 amounted to L.E. 5,949,720 in value, as against L.B. 1,471,813 for the previous year, a surplus of L.B. 4 477,907. The specie exported to Eogland was very small, only reaching total of L.B. 569,124, or L.B. 1,282,988 le=8 than in 1905, when this country sent LB. 1,852.112 to England.

In 1905 India sent specie to Egypt to the value of L.E. 1,462,509, botdid not export any during the past year. The exports of gold to Iodis in 1906 only amonpted to L.R. 120,907, as against L.B. 1,442,941 in 1905.
Turkey sent gold to the value of L.B. 1,451,443 in 1966, an increase of L.E. 795,159 in 1905. Egypt's exports of gold to Turkey amounted to L.B. 907,504, an increase of LR. 355,396 on 1905.
Specie to the value of L.B. 1,099,632 was received from France, an increase of L.E. 810,*95 on the figures for the previous year.. | The figures for the other countries are all under half a million.
DECEMBER'S STATISTICS.

The total number of English sovereigns which arrived in Egypt last December from England was of the value of L.B. 982,220. Engli-h sovereigns were imported from the following countries during December in the proportions given: Torkey, L.E. 287,071; Prance, L.E. 152 100; Austria, L.E. 25,477 ; Italy. L.E. 8,585; Greece, L.E. 1,173. The total amount of English sovereigns which arrived here last month reached the value of LE. 11.515.659. The imports of tbe corresponding month last year oply totalled the insignificant sam of L.B. 83,616.
The total of Napoleons imported last month amounted to L.E. 20,829. | Eogland sent Egyptian silver newly minted to the value of L.E. 13,930 last month.
The exports of specie in December amounted to only L.E. 40,714, as against L.E. 281,798 in the previous December. Tbe total exports consisted almost exclusively of English sovereigne, L.E. 40,281.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON MILLS.
div.p: SITUATION OF THE COMPANY.
(FROM A CORRESPONDENT.)

The annual ordinary meeting of the Egyptian Cotton Mille will be held in London to-day, in order to receive and pass the stooopts for the financial year ended on the 30th September, 1906. We have received the report of the directors, and on looking through the accounts we remark that the results of the year's work. ing are far from being satisfactory, sbowing, as they do, a loss of £930, which, added to that acogmulated op to now and amounting to | £19,738, makes a total loss of £20,668, which is equal to more than one-eighth of the capital of the company. The Profit and Loss account shows the following figures on the 30th Sep tember 1906:
RECEIPTS.
EXPENSES.

row.cell:
Insurance, Taxes, and other expenses
at Cairo

Interest paid on debit balances to
Banks, and on Mortgages

div.p: It does not seem permissible that such heavy expenses as those of the Loodon board of the company sbould be maintained, when the actual situation of the company is 80 unsatisfactory and jastifies no management other than that of the local board. On the other hand, interest paid to the banks on debit balances and on mortgage loans seems to us to fetter heavily the improvement of the future prospects of the company, whose industrial receipts do not exceed £9,500 per annom.

We most recognize, however, that the com pády's business appears to be in a better condition than formerly. If the company could reduce its administrative expenses, it wonld perhaps be possible for it to gradually liquidate its debts, as well as its losses. The balance sheet of the ocmpany on the 30th September last sums up thus:
lIABILITIES
Debenture capital
£30,000 6% first mortgage

£50,000 of which issues (inclu-
ding interest due

div.head: MR. ROBERTSON, M.P..
div.p: MORE PRESS COMMENTS.

Mr. Robertson's visit continues to aronse considerable interest in the local Press. His recent peregrinations in the provincer have especially attracted the attention of the native and foreign newspapers, and any and various comments are being passed on the visit of the Radical Member for the Tyneside division of Northumberland to the scene of the tragedy of Depishwai.

"Al Zaber," a Moslem daily newspaper of Cairo, pablisbes a leading article on Mr, Robertson to the following effect :-Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P, who after the Denishwai affair gave vent to some severe criticisms in the House of Commons upon the jadgment passed by the specially constituted coort in that case, is, an enthusiaetio Liberal and recently came to Egypt on a vieit. Here he was met by some enthusiastio members of the Nationalist Party, who labour ander the impression that he entirely sbares their political views. Bat the truth is that there is no real | accord between Mr. Robertson and them, except that both are zeslots. Mr. Robertson is a member of a British political party, the members of which believe that their policy is based on right principles and should be followed in the interests of their pation. Can any of our zealous Nationalists bring forward evidence to prove that their policy is based on similarly bigbminded aims ? When Mr. Robert on arrived in Cairo people went to greet him and exposed to him their opinions. Various were the romours broited abroad as to the objects of his visit and doubtless he is qnite ignorant of many of these reports. Many natives who have heard all abçat Mr. R sbertson's visit to the natives of Depishwai are now led thereby to believe in the emancipation of Egypt through his instrumentality, but if they had read what was published io the "Times" they would not be so bopeful. This gentleman is really among the strongest supporters of Eng. lisb poliay in Egypt, for all Englishmen desire to see their Egyptian policy to be firmly establisbed, and because some of them want to see whether there is anything to criticise in it, their action is merely due to a desire to improve their country's policy here. Under such circumstances therefore it is sheer nonsense to expect that some of the Erglish will help the Egyptians to get rid of the Occupation. Under the circomstances all that can be done is to co-operate with the English by coming to a good understanding with them in matters which can benefit Egypt hereafter. The overwhelming po ioy some of us Egyptians adopt will only produce the worst effects as we have already seen in some cases. We hope that Mr. Robertson's personal intercourse with some of the Nationalists will lead to these persons moderating their views and teach tbem to act in a befitting manner so that they may not mislead the whole nation.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p:
H.R.H. Prir ca Philip of Hangu hus left
Cairo for Upper Egypt

Prince and Princess Nicholas Brist ff, after
a short stay at the Carlton Hotel, Ramløb, left
to-day for Barope by the 8.3. Tebe.

Mrs. Ashley, daughter of Sir E-nest Cassel,
has arrived at the Savoy, bat is lesving in a
few days for Assonan.

Lady Magenis and Miss Winifred Corry are
also spending a few days at the Savoy prepar-
atary to going up the river.

Mr. Thorn, who is a well known visitor at
the Savoy, bas returned to his old quarters
accompanied by Mr. Arthur Capel.

Other visitors at the same hotel are Sir
Walter Palmer, Baron Morcqnes, and Mr.
Harrimar, who have jast returned after
very successful shooting expedition ; Mrs. and
Miss Love, who are intending to preg many
weeks among their old friends in Cairo; Mr.
Achille Pould, who is as well-knowo in London
as is in Paris ; Mr. and Mrs. Stephenson
Kant; and Mme and Mlle Barsoek. The
Vicomte and Vicomtesse de Villeneuve have t with them. M. and Mme Amor and Mlle
Errazieriz : all three ladier being noted for itbeir elegance and beauty; and another big party is composed of various members of the Shoemaker family from New York, and who are at present in monring for Mr. Shromsker, ljon, whose young widow, as Miss Paizer, was so well-known in the best American piroles.
Mr Fred. Scotter spent a couple of days at the Savoy en route for England. Mrs. Fred. Sootter will remain in Ansonan for some weaks longer, bat intends being back in the Riviers by Easter.
A correspondent states that the parchaser of Polesden Lacey, rear Dorking, the residence of the late Sir Clinton Dawkins, is Captain the Hon. Ronald Greville, elder son of Lord Greville.

Mr. W. J. Archer, C.M.G., formerly H.B.M. Consnl and Judge at Bangkok, and recently Judge of the Mixed Tribunals in Egypt, has taken op bis official position as Councillor of the Siamese Legation in London,
El Mr. Patrick Ad'erorentz, judge of the
Mixed Triboral, Mapsourah, is staying at the Carltop Hote', Rutleb.
Brevet Colonel P. A. Keppa, V C., 1.8.0., the new aide de camp to the King, who was promoted last week, won the Victoria Cross in
the Khartonmail
